review_title: Competitive pay and benefits, but some drawbacks due to being a satellite location
pros: Great pay, benefits, and vacation (start at three weeks, get a fourth week after 3 years, and a fifth after 5 years). Stock purchase plan, commuter reimbursement, lunch at one of the offices and daily snacks at the other, social events, weekly on-site yoga classes. There's flexibility in terms of working remotely, and work life balance is prioritized. If you're just getting started in your career there are lots of intern opportunities, as well as an intern community with their own events. Diversity is embraced. The male to female ratio is off, but that's typical in tech ... however, there's the Business Women's Network that both women and men are encouraged to participate in. As for the work itself, there are teams working on a range of different products. Also, change is pretty much the norm and there's always something new to learn.
cons: SAP's head office is in Germany, and that's where the majority of the leadership opportunities reside, at least for my line of work (user assistance development, aka technical writing). So if you're ambitious, you may find after a while that you can only go so far at SAP in Montreal.

pros: Great Employee Benefits (not the salary) Flexible work timings (based on the manager/project) WFH (again based on the manager) SAP Brand value You get to learn a lot of SAP product ecosystem
cons: Products are developed 8 years ago, hence technologies are not cutting edge. Technical scope of learning is minimum. Once you get the hang of the tools/frameworks it becomes very mundane and boring job. They have many proprietary tools /framework for which there are much better open source alternatives. Because of this ,community support is a challenge if you face any issues in those tools/frameworks. You cannot simply google it. Workload is uneven, product owners are spineless. They are pretty much confused in their minds and have no clarity. They will think a developer can do anything and they just have to give requirements. Sprint backlog estimation is big joke, they estimate a 1 month work for 8 days. Pay is low compared to its rivals. Not challenging and learning for java/python developers. Maintenance work

pros: - Work life balance - Best in India - Activities like hackathons, 3 months training in US called as SAP Academy of engineering - Free food, cab - Lots of outings - Coool employee friendly perks - Friendly colleagues
cons: - Low salary and monthly take home - Mostly inhouse SAP technologies like ABAP, UI5 which is of no use outside - No brilliant engineers around, most of the people are from service companies. - Poor engineering practices - Mostly maintenance and support work, very few good development projects - Very difficult to change teams - you have to wait 2yrs

pros: Nothing. Full of contracting work. Companies does not care about hiring full time. You can be a contractor here for 30 years for all they care
cons: Management is full of ignorant people. HR does not even care. Give them your life and invasion of privacy. Check your emails while you are on vacation. Non pay sick day? Better not take it even if it's not paid, let a lone paid. Managers tell you straight to your face insulting words even my colleague was facing mental issues. All my co workers and I wonder how the heck this place get rated as best place to work for? We are all miserable here. Maybe because when we went to HR they don't even care for these issues so nobody bother to report? Or tbh even scared of the pettiness they will stab you in the back and find out who writes this review and let you go. This place does not have a problem of letting people go. If you work here and you see it you know it's true they all do off source labors and contracting work that's it. The salary is great, yeah for full time workers. And guess what, you don't even stand a chance for full time even if you are an internal application. Disrespect is everywhere from management. Ready to yell at you for mistakes and never an appreciation. People are so petty they even find problems to report you for using phones and act like they are special. Oh and nobody holds doors for you with a smile ever here. They do it like it's a task and they are scared of socialization. Elevator talk? Forget it. A good morning from stranger? Forget it. Free food? You are ready to pay for pasta and sauce with no meatball? Meatball is extra charge! Oh and the lines re infinite and you basically fight for tables. And nobody cares about being rude to others but try to talk on the phone in the bathroom, rhey will look at you like you are crazy.

pros: Flexible work environment New things to learn every day great tech
cons: sometimes difficult to progress career

pros: Great team (scrum), great people, great atmosphere. Working with the newest and the most innovative technologies, such as Docker and Kubernetes, delivering to China. So many technologies and opportunities to learn, new concepts and projects are brought up all the time. Got to work with so much programming languages - Go, Node.js, JS, Java, Python, Groovi and I can keep going.. Awesome conditions regarding salary, holiday gifts, bonuses, etc.
cons: A lot of the developers are more than a decade in the company, and almost everybody (except students) are at least a few years (~5, 8 years), so some of the developers are not the most professional/driven out there. In addition, this causes a less young/fun/whatever vibe in the office. Some people might see this as a plus too - the company is very stable and its a good place of work to stay a life time. And! no real QA. That's a big con.

pros: I appreciate the amount of work they put into SAP ecosystem. It's something.
cons: What I do not and will not appreciate it for, is the piece of trash that came out of their idea. As a developer, you better feel suicidal if you think about starting working with the biggest disaster of a programming language. The language is locked down on their own kernel, so you can only do what they want you to do. Further more, the libraries of functions they put at your disposal may work, under some conditions, but you will never know that because they are not documented, anywhere. The only documentation you will find are the indians on forums. It's a straight up joke. Some of the mostly used functions are not even working properly, risking to end up spending a day or two finding an alternative. SAP is aware of their "amazing" work, that's why they are pushing their Cloud agenda so hard at every opportunity. They want everybody to ditch ABAP for ever and rely on other programming languages made by people who know what they are doing. Pathetic.

review_title: Little Support for Victims of Harassment
pros: Once you’re in, there’s good opportunity to navigate your career and switch to other areas as your interest evolve and adapt.
cons: I was hesitant to share this but was encouraged by other reviews of colleagues who seemed to have faced similar experiences with HR. SAP HR has a history of not supporting women who are facing harassment in the workplace. They are slow to act and when they do they will ask the person who reported the situation to make all the adjustments. Unless you escalate it, those accused of harassment will face little penalty while those who experienced it are made to feel guilty for even reporting it.

pros: Absolutely none for Business teams.
cons: Your experience at SAP will depend entirely on the department that you have joined. If you have joined SAP Labs, you can even retire from there. Most folks in SAP Labs have been there for 20+ years. It's very safe for techies, although SAP has unable to develop in house even 1 futuristic product over 35 years. Shocking! If you have joined SAP in the Business side (Sales/Marketing/Customer Facing roles), then there's a good chance you won't last for 20 months unless: 1. You have a god father in the company 2. You have joined as a management trainee If you join as a lateral recruit in the sales & marketing side, from other organizations, without knowing anyone powerful inside, then God help you. All the plum roles have already been grabbed internally by the old timers. The newly created experimental roles (whose life depends on whether the business did well or not), & the junior most roles are what is published for externals. So be very cautious before taking up a SAP offer. If you think you will rise purely on merit, you would be extremely disappointed. Finally, 90% + people in the Business teams don't earn much incentives. So you will rarely be earning your annual CTC.

review_title: Wonderful Company with a true employee focus!
pros: Leadership walks the talk. They truly seem to care about their employees and make you feel heard and understood. There is a culture of feedback, openness, and understanding and significant work life balance.
cons: I don't love the day to day of the role, but opportunities are endless across the rest of the company.

review_title: micro management is off the charts
pros: Good product set that works.
cons: Sales micro management is off the charts. I am required to give comprehensive deal status reports once a week. But in addition, I get 20 calls and emails daily asking for updates. Sales Management is entirely focused on simple next closing steps, layers of managers are tripping over each other to have the very latest info. I'm a high performer, will make over $500k this year, again. I can leave an important meeting, take 3 or more calls from various managers within 2 hours, and be berated for not having updated our CRM system called Harmony.

pros: The company offered Flex benefits, there is an onsite canteen available as well. There are a lot of employee benefits including gym, classes and enjoying group scheme discounts.
cons: Monetary Compensation below market rate

review_title: Great People, Great Opportunities, Great Benefits
pros: I've worked at SAP for many years and I'm continually impressed with how helpful employees are to each other. It drives me to make an extra effort so that anyone who comes to me leaves feeling that I removed a big unknown or roadblock for them. I believe these small behaviours add up to a great performance from the whole organization. After years at SAP, the one thing that has kept me is the ability to work on what I want. There are so many industries and technologies that SAP covers that you can start in a new technology area or run a large team or even have your new idea turned into a business. Finally, the benefits are very good - salary, bonuses, lunch card but more importantly I find for some are nice extras are the health benefits and support services like counseling to career path support and even resume writing. Also, I would like to add that working from home has been hugely helpful as I start a family as I can manage my life and work schedule together.
cons: I believe it's hard to say there is a con with SAP, or if there is, they will likely solve it. It's more like, one is looking for red and SAP only has blue, or blue, green, orange, black. So a con might be that SAP doesn't fit what one is looking for right now. Do some research and learn what SAP can offer you. SAP is a large company with many offices. If you want to work in a small social networking startup and like the challenge of fighting it out to overcome all odds for a big win (or big loss) then maybe SAP isn't for you. With that said, if you want to experiment in a safer environment, with strong support services, access to customers and access to experienced people then SAP could work for you.

review_title: Cloud groups have really gone down hill since SAP's takeover
pros: Decent benefits, work/life balance, and a lot of products to sell.
cons: Can't trust what leadership promises or your terms of commission agreeements to be real. Presidents club, goal post changed mid-year (IE: Club target was one 100% of your annual number in January and is now 130% as of an early July announcement. Uncertain commissions (constant unexplained claw backs with no recourse, just have to accept you are not getting paid). Leadership is too weak in the cloud groups to do anything about any of it. Culture is changing in Sales. We used to feel appreciated especially at end of month and end of quarter pushes. Now it is just a nasty & cold, build-your-own sandwich platter and SAP constantly finding any excuse to pay you less than you were promised and less than you deserve.

Business units such as this make SAP a terrible place to work

pros: Work-life balance is encouraged. Employees seem to be treated well, respected and everyone has a voice. They are also expected to take control of their own careers. No hand-holding here unless absolutely necessary. The ability to work from home is amazing and this notion seems to constant throughout the company. Compensation seems to be fair. Most people seem very nice, this seems to be a constant at all levels from junior, experience, senior and management staff. There is a certain level of warmth and friendliness through the company. This is encouraging as there seems to be a high level of collaboration, non-combative behaviour and generally, there is a an emphasis being team players and always aiming for a win-win scenario in everything. The office and work environment are nice, with good facilities, recreational areas and well-equipped desk although I'm not personally a fan of the open office concept but I understand it is simply how the office is arranged. Generally and broadly speaking, everyone I've encountered seems to be incredibly skilled at their jobs. This is a positive thing as this hopefully means that there is plenty of room of competent people and little room for freeloaders or incompetent people. Work is fun and challenging (for me at least). The culture is fantastic so far. The reviews, comments, and opinions of SAP as a company has indeed been very true. It is indeed a great place to work.
cons: The company is huge with numerous departments. Navigating around every aspect is incredibly intimidating and potentially difficult to understand easily. There is a huge learning curve in understanding the core concept of the company (SAP is broadly a software company but it's also so much more) and there are many, almost too numerous products to understand. The ability to take charge of one's own career is both a pro and a con as new hires can get lost without guidance from their managers.

pros: - The company's long-term prospects are looking great. Vancouver location especially has lots of opportunity, because it's home to development on SAP's most successful "homemade" (non-acquisition) cloud product (SAP Analytics Cloud). The product is also a part of the core strategy now. - Very respectful, healthy place to work at. The company has really good values, result being that everyone is professional, respectful and nice to each other. - Lots of really smart people to work with and learn from. - There's lots of really challenging, interesting work to go around. Lots of movement towards newer technologies as well. There will be no shortage of demand for development work, or opportunities to challenge yourself if that's what you want to do. - Good work-life balance is promoted. Devs aren't on-call all the time. No expectation to be constantly crunching, unlike other places. - High performers are recognized and rewarded. Lots of opportunity for advancement. - People with ideas and opinions on how things can improve are encouraged to share, especially if you're willing to be part of the solution.
cons: - SAP is in the "A-tier" of compensation, but not "S-tier". There are a few other companies in Vancouver that pay the top of the top (about 2.5x the average), whereas SAP is in the level below that (2x the average). The kind of talent at SAP is about the same, so you do take a pay cut in exchange for better work-life balance. This also causes issues with losing some really good talent to competitors. - Culture changes as product in Vancouver Labs starts to mature. Less startup-like perks, less free-flow spending on miscellaneous things like free food, events, etc. - Technology challenges such as old frameworks that can be difficult to work with (SAP UI5), technical debt, etc. Still lots of work left to overcome these challenges, all the while needing to balance the need for aggressive product growth.

pros: Great culture, amazing work-life balance, lots of opportunities to learn new things and interact with other teams, amazing lunch program for Vancouver employees, friendly people.

pros: The pros of this Job is that is it a 9-5, but the hours can be flexible. You never have to take your work home, it's challenging in the sense that there is always something to learn and grow since HANA is such a huge product you can never entirely learn everything.
cons: - This is an incident type role when you start you get the impression that you are part of development but you quickly learnt that it is a support role. Every day is endless amounts of tickets to solve and you never feel like you are productive because of its a continuous conveyor belt. - You will quickly feel the effects of being pigeon holed. - You don't have much time to work on your own personal development because you are constantly working on tickets. - Progression in this role doesn't seem to be fair overall, and there is not a lot of transparency in this role.

pros: Definitely the people - you can always count on your team to come back to something when needed, rally around, help any time you need it. Good benefits. Good working hours. Flexible management style, trust and cooperation, very diverse environment. Working hard on diversity and inclusion. Leadership I find are inclusive of younger and different genders overall.
cons: Not always simple to navigate, which I suppose is the nature of a very large, international company. But doesn't always run simple. Many processes and long periods to get things done. Channels and sales could enjoy better collaboration (which is undoubtedly the same for all organisations). Not as relaxed in terms of dress code in my view as it could be; still quite formal and 'office style' especially for women. As other companies like Google and start up businesses relax their style maybe SAP could try that too.

review_title: High caliber of people and great culture
pros: Flexibility is great for most roles - helps if you have a busy personal/family life. Global environment where people are genuinely respectful of different cultures. Managers and employees are generally not afraid to share info or help their colleagues learn and grow (compared with other companies where you might see intense territorialism or job protectionism).
cons: Can be intense workload and time commitment depending on your team and leader. Upward mobility is much more likely if you're based in one of the major offices where there are more high level execs. Tendency to focus more heavily on the youngest generations - ageism can be a thing.

review_title: A well-run ship with good values, but that is drifting a bit
pros: - SAP treats its employees like human beings, not like batteries to be drained - Lots of opportunities for training and advancement - Good quality of life and relatively low stress
cons: - Working outside of the main office in Germany can feel like being a 2nd class citizen at times, where we are shut out from decision making and given less interesting work to do - There is a trend in the company to build open floor plan offices without even cubicle walls. Developers are largely introverts working on tasks that require total concentration for hours at a time. It should be obvious that the open floor plan is a DISASTER for this kind of employee. It's hard to estimate precisely, but my productivity has dropped to probably 30% of what it was in a cubicle. Imagine the overall impact on employee morale, as well as the bottom line when you need to hire 3 people to do 1 person's job in this kind of environment.

review_title: SAP allows you to grow without having to change organizations
pros: I have plenty of flexibility in my work hours. Since I work on a truly global team there is no need to be at the office although the office is wonderful and most SAP locations have special access suites for lawyer office which means no fighting for meeting rooms. There are several programs that allow you to expand your experience- The fellowship program and the experience exchange program. One allows you jump into another job role entirely for 6 mos or more and sometimes in international locations. The latter program is a shorter job shadowing or project secondments in other departments which also comes with a travel budget. Employee engagement is valued and worked on. Every location in SAP worldwide has free lunches and some places free breakfast.
cons: Pay is never the highest. The pace of change can be slow for those that want to come and change things quickly but this deliberation also helps with stability.

review_title: SAP Palo Alto is a good place to start, but not a good place to stay
pros: Work-life balance Beautiful campus in Palo Alto Healthy Company Culture & Values Good Early Talent Programs Great food on campus
cons: - Terrible compensation at SAP silicon valley/bay area. Even though I have always been a top performer in my team (I've been SAP Catalyst for several times), even with my promotions/progressions I have stayed at 70% of my level's median salary. Raises have been around 3-4%. My only option (I'm bound to SAP through my Visa and slow GC processing) was to switch to a company SAP acquired, which I did. Suddenly, it was the most normal thing in the world to be paid 100% of my level's median salary. - Slow Green Card processing - I'm not affected by this, but many of my peer complain about it. SAP uses Fragomen for Visa processing and they are terribly slow. Expect for a single email to answered by Fragomen after 4 weeks, sometimes two months. Now figure how many years some people wait to just get their GC process started. - Incompetent people & product management - Most managers have no idea how cloud software is built and how dev teams have to be organized. - Reporting lines across the ocean and back - Terrible product quality: I do not know a single SAP product that I enjoy using. Everything is just hacked together. - In the very end, no real value-creating work: Software development at SAP is mainly about stitching together acquisitions with our core. All the newer stuff (machine learning, IoT blockchain, etc.) is done at comparatively low investment (politically and with resources) mostly driven by non-technical people instead of "value engineering". - I haven't seen a single "innovation" project succeed at SAP within the past 5 years (Leonardo, etc.). Everything is just stitched together somehow with no real strategy.

pros: Very friendly environment, friendly people to work with and the company is amazing regarding employees. They really look after each of us.

review_title: A company that really cares about you and invests in your future!
pros: I have so many positive things to say about SAP. Although the company is large, there are abundant resources and people to connect with to further your career. I have spent time at a small startup and SAP often has that small-company energetic, change-the-world vibe and I know that is rare or nonexistent in large companies elsewhere. The Executive Leadership is trustworthy and transparent. Motivation to do your best work abounds, I really enjoy working here.
cons: Sometimes certain elements of vision can get clouded through the vastness of a 100K employee company, but you truly can seek out lots of information about where SAP is headed internally and educate yourself. There are also normal pains of navigating a large organization to find the right resources, but SAP is committed to "Run Simple" and we're making improvements.

review_title: SAP has offered me the greatest growth opportunities and gave me support through personal circumstances
pros: _ Very human company _ Great people to work with _ Place for great innovation _ focus on true agility and being Agile VS doing Agile
cons: _ Complexities and processes when working for a big multi national

review_title: So good I had to come back.
pros: Fabulous culture. I find myself surrounded by passionate, intelligent colleagues who are always willing to pitch in to help when needed. I fully embrace SAP's mission to improve people's lives and make the world run better. I worked at SAP for years, left for 5 years and then decided to come back.
cons: It's a large organization and like any large organization it can be difficult to navigate, especially when first joining.

review_title: Entrepreneurial spirit, collaborative, tons of growth potential
pros: CAREER FLEXIBILITY: I started my career in pre-sales, moved to product development, and looking for a new challenge, I reinvented my career in marketing. I can't imagine another company where I'd have been able to reboot my career *with support from management* as I have here. COLLABORATIVE CULTURE: The level of collaboration here is really amazing. Talk to SAPers and the most common "plus" you hear about the company is "the people"... Can't find information you're looking for? Send an email to someone you don't know who has that keyword in their profile, and no matter where in the world they are, they're going to help you or help you find someone with the information. I've never had someone say to me "that's not my job". It's amazing. And uncommon. ENTREPRENEURIAL SPIRIT: SAP is big, but everyone I talk to agrees the thing we love is the way you can mold your role/job and career here - and if you decide you want to leave to try something different or you're taking a break from work to take care of family, and want to come back to SAP you'll find that additional experience viewed as a positive (and in the case of a break to care for children/family, you will find support for your re-entry). That said, if you are someone who wants a job that's highly-directed (strong oversight, active management by your boss on a day to day basis with daily feedback/input) this is not going to be a place for you in most cases. This is a highly-independent work environment in the vast majority of cases. CULTURE: I'm going to sound marketing-y for a minute, but imagine working for a company that is EDGE Certified (leading business certification for gender equality), has a global Tech Diversity & Inclusion team, has offices and customers in ~180 countries; has a major Corporate Social Responsibility organization that coordinates volunteers for service activities, and during 2 mos of the year offers paid time off to participate in volunteer activities; and donation-matching is offered. SAP has been in industry leader since 2014 delivering an Annual "Integrated Report" which considers the corporate impact on the environment and our sustainability, to use a holistic view of our total impact beyond finances as our measure of success each year. We also have a range of employee interest groups including Business Women's Network, Black Employees Network, and are one of Workplace Pride's Top 10 companies in the world for LGBTQ-friendly workplace environment and policies. Inter-cultural training is provided to help teams in different countries understand how to work and communicate more effectively with each other. This is not about political correctness; it's about being respectful of others' cultures and different points of view, even if you have different beliefs. GLOBAL REACH/IMPACT: If you eat it, drink it, drive it, wear it, or use it in your daily life, our customers probably make it. E.g., 78% of the world's food supply is delivered by SAP customers (including 82% of the world's chocolate supply, and 72% of the world's beer). That is incredible - but it also is a key reason our Board and CEO have a mission to "Help the world run better and improve people's lives". If your company touches 70% of financial transactions that happen daily, globally, you have an opportunity and a responsibility to think about how that reach can benefit people - not just ourselves. A lot of people struggle wanting to work somewhere that makes a difference - I've found working at SAP I have a long-term career where I do make a difference, in ways that I can't imagine other companies could. Very cool. SUPPORT TO INNOVATE & TAKE RISKS: the CEO says "tell it like it is" and take informed risks and as far as I've seen, this is supported (standard caveat of, "when it's done in a constructive, and respectful way". This may partly be a function of German work culture, but I've found the openness here refreshing compared with friends' experiences. PURPOSE-DRIVEN: SAP's mission FOR YEARS is "Help the world run better and improve people's lives". This was our mission before it was 'cool'. This was our mission before terms like 'green-washing' and 'virtue-signaling' came into mainstream conversations. We have had CSR programs for more than 20 years; we have had sustainability programs for at least a decade; we've had excellent benefits like paid parental leave for adoptions, paid bereavement leave (immediate family ), affordable healthcare, paid vacation starting at 3 wks (sick days are separate from vacation days), subsidized public transportation, and our larger offices there are employee cafeterias where you can get subsidized lunches (hot food, not just deli-style food), sourced locally when possible, and with vegetarian and vegan options. TRAINING & CAREER SUPPORT: a robust program for growing within the company means once you join SAP, you can do a wide range of jobs and change careers - as I did - multiple times without leaving the company. I personally attribute this to the German business model, which brings in young talent and nurtures it, versus the typical American model where recruiters look for existing-employed individuals and attempt to hire them away. This model means a lot of people stay at SAP for a long time compared to other tech companies - but the ability to move around within the company and try different jobs keeps your career fresh and interesting. There are formal and informal job training programs, formal Mentoring and Coaching programs, internal recruiters to help people move around, and - one of the best things - opportunities to work in other countries for short term or permanent assignments, with the most opportunities in Asia, Europe, and Latin America.
cons: LARGE BUSINESS COMPLEXITY: the entrepreneurial spirit is real, but SAP still is a large enterprise, with a broad portfolio of software and there's just a layer (or layers) of complexity that's unavoidable. Approvals are layered and things don't move as fast as you want/should. No worse than other places, better than many. RE-ORGs: all companies in tech go through reorganizations more frequently than companies in traditional fields like manufacturing, but SAP is somewhat known for moving teams and organizations around faster than average. Depending on your role in the company, you could have a new focus in your job every year without actually moving to a new team. If you hate change and having to constantly learn new things, this will be challenging for you. But if you get bored easily, this could be a positive even if it can be frustrating.

pros: -Benefits: 401k, great health insurance plans, employee stock plans -Vacation days: been here for 3 years and i have 25 vacation days which is pretty decent. -Work from Home: depends on the team, but it's very common here and most managers are very flex with this. -Opportunity for Growth: Lot's of opportunity for growth -Cool events: They throw some cool parties if you're near an office. Holiday parties and Summer Picnics are pretty fun and they really go all out with the events. They also bring in awesome guest speakers like Jill Biden, Elizabeth Smart, Jerry Greenfield, etc. and i really look forward to these
cons: -Training: almost all training is done online now and everyone knows the quality and effectiveness of online training... -Lack of technical training: there are soooo many different types of customer support / enablement teams and no one has really any technical or functional knowledge of the products. -Work Life Balance in Consulting: It's great that the executives preach about work life balance, but everyone knows in consulting, that doesn't necessarily exist if you're working for a large, strategic customer with unrealistic timelines -Sales vs. Professional Services: conflicting KPIs within these orgs causes lots of headbutting and undercutting. I cant tell you how many times sales people have sold/promised something that doesn't exist without talking to product and then they just dump it on the consultants after the deal is signed and they get their comp. -Products: lots of product shortcomings. It's extremely frustrating to be working on strategic accounts and implementing a product that has lots of room for improvement, but SAP has laid off product resources to hire more customer enablement people that sit around and blow smoke.

review_title: Great company with a poor compensation strategy
pros: SAP is a big place, sometimes there's literally a job for every little task that can be thought of. If you are great at networking and self-promoting you could move around quite a bit within the company. There's a lot of fringe benefits and learning opportunities that are offered. Some are good for development and some are good for a nice distraction to your day to day.
cons: This is a big place with lots of people. Organizations are complex and there's a lot of overlap. It can be hard to operate across organizational lines when you aren't even sure which organizations do what and owns what. It can feel like you're working within an amorphous blob that can only roll uphill or downhill. In addition the compensation strategy is poor. This is a sales driven company, everyone else is treated like "everyone else". Promotions are driven by "who's next in line" vs "who's deserving". Since compensation isn't driven by performance, they do try to be creative about finding other means to promote performance but those efforts generally fall flat and they themselves are funded enough to meet the demand. The compensation culture incentives position movement (even lateral ones) rather than performance to increase your compensation.

review_title: Innovation and Transformation at a Big Tech Company? You bet!

Opportunity to work with global colleagues, expand your own point-of-reference.
cons: Processes and procedures (that are necessary) can feel confining. This is sort of a con, but actually a plus. You have to learn to connect and collaborate so that your work and development integrates and aligns with other projects and technology directions.

I've been part of Concur pre-acquisition and post-acquisition (SAP) and the culture has not changed even in the slightest. The work-life balance, focus on health and wealth, individual career and personal growth, and the complete buy-in from leadership has not changed. SAP is an amazing global organization that does the right things and takes care of their people.
cons: Concur is the 800lb gorilla in the room and continues to be the market leader in the Travel & Expense software. Innovation and product improvements are the two areas that need more focus, but changing such a massive cloud based software product that is used by millions daily around the globe is a challenge, but they're making strides. SAP is one of the top 4 ERP and Business Suites giants in the world, but "Running Simple" is sometimes the hardest part of using SAP products.

pros: Genuinely fosters a sense of caring about employees Great company culture Fairly competitive salaries Good benefits
cons: 1. SAP varies the benefits it offers its employees based on geography. Employees in the US, for example, get significantly less paid parental leave than those in Europe. Ex. In Europe, the *minimum* a new mother can take is 15 weeks, and she can take up to 26. In the US, the *maximum* is 12 weeks. For a company that talks a lot about taking care of its employees, it seems somewhat hypocritical to treat them all differently, working within the minimum guidelines laid down by law. 2. Internal raises and salary increases are fairly stagnant. Practically the only way to get a significant raise within SAP is to get a new job in a different department. This is awful, because then those with much higher expertise and product knowledge just... leave. Regular actual raises for increased expertise and product knowledge would save SAP a fortune in hiring and training newbies, as well as improve employee morale and help retain good workers.

pros: Provides a great platform to work, great people and continuous learning . Excellent Managers to support

review_title: 20th century technology and lots of propaganda
pros: It's a tech company. Pay is reasonable, given the lowball "salaries" (if one is lucky to have one) that have become standard in the economy. Benefits are good.
cons: Zero visibility to those on the ground. All major decisions are made in Germany, and are often shortsighted and/or senseless. Developers who aren't in Waldorf or Bangalore often get the short end of the stick, while expecting to conform to half-year deadlines. Teams are spread out across timezones, making it difficult to collaborate effectively. Core backend technology is severely outdated and causes a lot of problems with modern client-side application implementations (i.e. mobile).

Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Flexible working locations - I do 100% remote work, but there are offices that I can go to when I need some people energy. Access to any SAP offices worldwide. Flexible working hours - many people work 4 days a week or on alternative working time. This can be arranged depending on the nature of your work and your team. Investment on people - SAP invests A LOT on people's wellbeing and growth. The company culture supports helping each other as well. I've been benefiting from shadowing and mentoring of amazing people around the world. Good benefits, free lunch and free gym.
Cons
The main London office is far from central London - hence the remote work flexibility! Large company - bureaucracy and silo can happen.

ltant in Sydney
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Before I joined the “real” SAP, I’ve doing & using SAP R3/4 for 15+ years, however only now I know more about SAP, the culture, wow, and a lot more. 1. Buddy program- you always have some colleague assigned to help you and support you wherever and whenever; 2. You clearly feel you are welcomed and loved by your team ; 3. Your work life balance is one of the KPI of your boss; 4. Ask questions, don’t be afraid and you always get answers; 5. Numerous tools and methodology far far beyond imagination, like jumping into ocean of knowledge; 6. You are always spoiled by HR with so many activities, parties, warm emails, ballots; 7. Maternity and parental leave for sure; 8. You get birthday greetings from global CEO! 9. A true diversity environment, just be yourself; 10. Same in any SAP offices I’ve been traveled to.
Cons
Not any , if I can think out, maybe the salary is not very competitive (I was hesitating on the offer, and I know some people gave up and chose other higher salaries).

review_title: A great place to work! A good place to grow!
pros: SAP has a lot of different positions and roles that can help you find the perfect fit for your career. Furthermore, international exposure during daily job helps you build a profile that is ever appealing. Last but not least, compensation and benefits are really hard to match by any other employer.
cons: Once in a specific position, it is quite complex to define or identify a clear development plan that includes both professional skill and salary making sometimes hard to fully engage yourself.

review_title: Great company to work with unparralel benefits offerings!
pros: - Very good benefits plan - very few companies can match it , Globally. - A lot of flexibility and work life balance -A lot of career opportunity internally, opportunity to try new roles for short or longer duration -Learning opportunity is great! Trainings and loads of trainings...so much so it's difficult to get time and attend all. -Social enterprising and support to various social causes, supporting organisations those support social causes -Inclusion and diversity- a great place to work, very inclusive culture
cons: - More women participation is needed at managerial and executive level. - Internal alignment of the businesses is needed, streamline the Org structure.

pros: SAP is the whole package. I've not had a single negative experience. In fact, my mind is continually blown as to how great a place it is to work. Management is brilliant, colleagues are friendly, intelligent, supportive, sociable, welcoming and fun. Everyone is passionate and proud of what they do which fosters an extremely positive environment. The benefits are also insanely good. Managers work on your personal goals and professional development with you too through an informal chat, I've never felt so supported in my life! Technology is in no way skimped on, they really invest the way a technology company should. A lot of companies are all talk, but SAP are genuinely fantastic and I cannot recommend it more highly as a place of work.
cons: Zero cons, I've got nothing bad to say as it's the most incredible place I have ever worked. I hadn't realised how toxic my previous workplaces were until I experienced life at SAP with their refreshing take on workplace values, putting the money where their mouth is and truly making it a fulfilling journey.

review_title: Great place to work for anyone who enjoys a challenge and isn’t put off by change
pros: High level of individual freedom (flexible working hours and location, I can shape or influence key aspects of my day-to-day work). Great amenities and support infrastructure: sport and shower facilities to help keep fit, preventative health offerings, strong family policy, regular health and self-care initiatives, regular social events. Generous compensation and benefits. You won’t be bored. And the pace of change means that opportunities to learn and diversify present themselves regularly. There are hundreds of online and classroom training classes to brush up all kinds of expert and soft skills. Most are open to everyone. The leadership style in my team is open and constructive. Like in any large organisation, styles vary across teams, but on the whole I believe SAP does try to live its core values. The team. I feel privileged to work with so many smart and talented people in a very cooperative environment.
cons: Information overload: It’s a large organization, in a multi-faceted and complex business. It can be a challenge to filter out what you really need to know or learn. We need to react to change, so we reorganize a lot. This can feel like unnecessary disruption. Experts are valued but fast rack careers are rare. Formal promotion can take longer than expected. Although the company and managers strongly advocate a good work-life balance, the workload in some areas still makes this challenging.

ltant in Walldorf, Baden-Wurttemberg, Baden-Wurttemberg
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
There are really very good benefits, such as gym (with a trainer that prepares a plan) company car, many different learning opportunities, online, webinars, etc. There's mentoring and coaching and a series of events for all kind of personal interest (from family related, culture related, technology related) it's a really good atmosphere where all internal communication is informal. We have several options to change path internally and work in different areas according to one's interest.And we always come across international colleagues that make our dily work more enriching. The best thing is the cantine, food for fee at lunch with 3 or more options for menu, salad buffet, and dessert. Free coffee and tea and YEAH! the option to work remotely.
Cons
A big big company is very difficult to coordinate and the amount of bureaucracy in some processes is overwhelming. Get teams from different areas to work together is complicated. Despite the many many options to change to different works and areas, grow a career is very difficult. After some years there's a stagnation, specially for women.

review_title: SAP has a unique, five-star Corporate Identity!
pros: !Diversity! Your language, your appearance, your color, your backround (PhD or bachelor or master or none of those) doesn't matter to anyone. Everybody is part of the team. !Language! If there is a team with 15 people having a discussion in german and anyone not-fluent in german joins, the group continues in english. I call that impressive and unique. !workspace + software/apps! You want to work with a high-tech laptop, desk, mobile, headset (Jabra)? The most recent apps from Microsoft Office (Onedrive, Outlook, Sharepoint, MS Teams, Skype) and others (Slack, JIRA, Confluence, Mural, Jam)? !summary! SAP offers all of that for every single employee. A clear PRO from my perspective
cons: !location! The german headquarter is in Walldorf next to Heidelberg. The campus itself is nice - yet this aint Berlin, Hamburg or Munich.

review_title: Best Company I Ever Worked For
pros: I'm part of a truly multicultural workforce, that pulls together to achieve amazing software solutions, and to share information about the user assistance that we produce. There's genuine scope for personal development, through excellent, free training courses, talks, and conferences. Knowledge sharing across the organization is encouraged and supported at every turn, so you're always learning and growing. I appreciate being appreciated and trusted, and having the autonomy to set my own targets, challenge conventional ways of working, and add value in more ways than I was hired to. Having 'SAP' on your CV seems to count for quite a lot when it comes to future employment, but right now, I am not interested in any other employer - SAP ticks all the boxes for me.
cons: SAP is a very large organization, so there's an understandable disconnect between the corporate vision and strategy, which seems to reside in the USA, and the day-to-day activities of development teams. SAP managers make a real effort to bridge that gap, and the company never appears to conceal or withhold information from employees, but the ultimate purpose of an employee can still seem remote or abstract when viewed from a local team perspective.

review_title: A good employer who could be the best employer
cons:
ltant in Berlin
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
There are many positive things at SAP. Work-life balance is for me the first. Inclusion and diversity are also priorities in the company. Salaries are good compared to the average in my city and in the industry. SAP embraces change, it might be slow or imperfect but it still happens somehow!
Cons
This company has turned from a software into a sales-driven company. Therefore working in the creation of software solution is somehow less rewarded than selling these solutions or the ones the company keeps acquiring. Integration (not only technology-wise) is the next challenge. We still have a long way ahead of us.

review_title: Comfortable place to work, poor direction and rewards
pros: laid back environment Once fully ramped up and proficient, you can get by comfortably Rarely too demanding for a long period of time. Often work goes through busy and quiet periods. A lot of autonomy given: as long as work gets done by end of the week everyone is happy Work is manageable for the most part, can telework twice a week
cons: Salary is poor compared to our competitors. Legacy issue at SAP, has always been the case, and nothing seems like this will change any time soon. Management seems like they're doing what they can with resources they have, however don't expect frequent events throughout the year, or much in the way of making employees feel valued. Seems to be running on a shoestring budget. Ireland is low-cost center compared to other countries, and it certainly feels that way. Compensation for increased workload / skill is minimal. Don't expect big year on year increases, regardless of the work you do. Long term strategy and goals are defined, but do not feel achievable for the most part. Targets set by board / upper management feel unrealistic, and overly ambitious. Decisions made by upper management often are confusing and contradictory. Told to work efficiently and push for the strategy, but all the hard work in the world won't help meet targets. The salesperson attitude of pushing services / upgrades on customers is prevalent, but disheartening. Some managers have been in the role for many years, very stuck in their ways and closed off to criticism and suggestions Company wants to hire and promote innovative thinkers, but new ideas are often ignored due to costs or lack of medium / long term commitment Training is poor to non-existent. Again management cites costs in refusing to provide proper training to employees. Management wants skilled, motivated, innovative workforce, while not wanting to pay for it

location: Newport, South East England, England, England
review_title: Amazing place to work full of opportunity and great people
cons:
ltant in Newport, South East England, England, England
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Working at SAP is an adventure where I am always being challenged to do my best. It is a place where you can grow, learn, and better yourself in a truly supportive environment. It is both a large global corporation where you can travel and develop friendships all across the world, and at the same a close knit group of people where you never feel you are just a number or unappreciated for the work you do.
Cons
The only downsides to working at SAP are those that are part of every large corporation. It seems that you are constantly in meetings and there is always some new buzzword or management practice that results in a reorganisation of your team. Not really a negative thing though, as it means you are always meeting new people and taking training that you can apply to all areas of your life. It gives you a chance to grow and take the opportunity for advancement or change of career path within the company.

review_title: Meh. Could be good, could be not... If your manager is reasonable, your job could be great.
cons:
ltant in Reston, VA
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Very interesting work Some really great people and managers
Cons
Some managers and employees are very cliquey 120% effort expected all the time They review on a curve, so someone always has to come out unsatisfactory

pros: - We can begin between 8am and 10am and finish between 4pm and 6pm. - Free food but the quantity is limited. - Gym onsite with classes and a funny instructor. - Two days working from home every week. However, you cannot work from home neither Fridays nor Mondays. - When you work on a Saturday or Sunday, you get 1,5days in exchange (instead of 1 day as other companies do). You get 2 days in exchange when you work a bank holiday. - The pension plan is really good in comparison with other companies. If you put 4% of your salary and the company adds a 10%. Other companies only match what you put. - You can create a development plan and get advice from HR. I have seen people moving to other departments but have also seen people trying hard and didn´t succeed. It all depends how helpful your manager is. When a person in my team tried to move to another department, his current manager said to the future manager, “we need him here. We cannot afford losing him from our team”. This person eventually left the company. - You can charge your electric car (if you have one) for free.
cons: - Several People in the team have suffered burnouts. Since January this year SAP is not replacing people who left the team. This means than the ones staying have double of work and end up suffering burnouts. - The salaries are completely unfair. People who began years ago were offered less salary than the ones beginning nowadays. Despite all the salaries reviews done every March, some salaries are still far away from being at the same level. There are cases with €3000 of difference between the new and old people. The best is that you cannot talk about these differences with your manager because it is written in the contact that you cannot say your salary to anybody. If you try to point out this difference, they will try to force you to say the name of the person and this employee will get in trouble. - The salary increases really little. Sometimes the salary increase is €450 gross a year! - You always have to queue to go to the toilet in the main building. There are really few toilets for the number of people working there. - The main building is an eco-friendly building. This mean that sometimes is warm and sometimes is cold. I still remember when everybody was sent home during the irish heat wave last year. There were only 30ºC outside but we all felt like chicken being roasted inside an oven in the main building.

pros: There's a lot to love about SAP: amazing colleagues, global presence, learning and development opportunities, good benefits, the ability to work from wherever, and inspiring leadership. You are empowered to do your job without someone breathing down your neck, which is key. There are a ton of growth opportunities (almost an overwhelming amount), and you're encouraged to seek out learning to broaden your horizons and shake up your day-to-day. I love working here!
cons: Some of the technologies that are role-critical are dated and can make doing my job harder, which is very counterintuitive considering we're a tech company. There's a tinge of politics in certain parts of the business, but I wouldn't consider them to be a rampant problem especially considering the size of our company. Growth opportunities are definitely aplenty, but it can be overwhelming and difficult to progress depending on which BU you're in.

pros: Perks- work from home , leaves, annual events, team events, car lease policy, personal loan, SAP shares
cons: it is totally dependent on the team you get into. it could be wonderful or stressful experience.

pros: I've now worked for SAP for nearly 12 years following the Business Objects acquisition. In this time I've had some great opportunities to grow and develop in my roles. There are some great managers at SAP and also I enjoy the way SAP constantly want to innovate. The company is generous at remuneration and benefits and does have good award mechanisms in place. If you have the right manager, there is also a good work / life balance. In my time at SAP I have taken advantage of many CSR & other work programs, that are not offered at every business. SAP really does try and support employees.
cons: There is a real lack of strong management. There are some great managers at SAP but over the years I've also seen really bad managers progress who have no respect from their employees. This can be frustrating. I think the people survey is often done and then overlooked and managers are not invested in to ensure they are the right person for the job. I also feel that we need to think about the customer more. Over the past few years we have really lost our way with customer empathy and make demands on customers that really shouldn't be made. We need to stop running before we can walk.

location: São Paulo, São Paulo, São Paulo

cons: More popular events to position our New Solutions (IBP, IAM, etc)

review_title: An arrogant software company with ambitions to become a leader in the cloud.
cons:
ltant in Walldorf, Baden-Wurttemberg, Baden-Wurttemberg
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Benefits (Company car, free food, etc.). Mobile working. Flexible working hours. A lot of friendly colleagues and nice offices. A lot of knowledgeable colleagues.
Cons
Old people with an on-premise mindset are driving the company. It is very difficult to get promoted at SAP. The rules for getting a promotion are not clear. Even if one takes an initiative and applies and gets an internal job with a higher career level, HR and management will find a way to prevent the candidate from getting a promotion. Salaries for experienced talents that have been for a long time at SAP are at least 20 - 30% less than their real market values. New hires are not always the best fit for the company. Development work is mostly offshored to cheaper countries which affects the software quality delivered. Cloud business models for most of the products do not match today's market prices and expectations. Internal processes within the company need optimization Too many organizational heirarchy levels. Reorgs are constantly disrupting work. No true / real innovations that have been brought to the market since a very long time.

pros: Innovative, Progressive, Inclusive company which supports internal growth more than any other company I've worked at
cons: It's a large company, there is a lot of process which not everyone can live with

pros: I was referred to SAP by a former colleague. The company was on my radar but I never had a good understanding of their business. I learned more through the recruiting process and was blown away to hear about their impact on the world's business community. They power so many companies across the globe! What really hooked me in and got me interested in working at the company was their employee value proposition tagline of "Bring Everything You Are, Become Everything You Want." That assured me that SAP could be a place where I could innovate within my specialty and grow my career. I've been with the company for almost nine months and I can honestly say it's an awesome place to work and grow. review_title: High rewards if you can handle high pressure
pros: Benefits are great, everyone gets a laptop and mobile phone. Working from home is easy and generally acceptable across the business although it's not openly encouraged all the time. Stock options and private Healthcare are top tier, pension and bonus is also very good.
cons: Extremely high pressure. I always thought I could handle pressure until I worked here. If you're in a team that has anything to do with sales then you can expect to work 14+ hour days for the last month of the quarter. If you're supporting sales then they treat you like dirt and speak down to you. It's a very sales focused company, if you don't get on board with the sales culture then you'll be left behind. I saw 3-4 employees break down at their desks multiple times over the course of 12 months due to workload and pressure from senior staff.

pros: Benefits - I would say these are the biggest Pros of SAP. The free lunches in the canteen and your other benefits to select - 360 health reviews, private medical, shares etc. Working from home also was a bonus - especially if you don't live within an easy commute distance which i didn't.
cons: Management was terrible. HR was terrible. I didn't get an exit interview either. When i handed in my notice, management doubled my work (with 2wks left) and after asking for help (which was ignored) i made a complaint. Instead of working with me to resolve the issues, i was told it was my fault as i'd decided to leave and if it was not clear already this is the behaviour you will expect to see in SAP. It was already on record and management were aware that i have a diagnosed mental health condition, whilst that isnt my fault or theirs - they didnt manage me with any concern or care for my wellbeing the entire length of my service to SAP. They just pile on more and more pressure until you burn out, make yourself unwell or have a breakdown. This happened to me. If you work at SAP be prepared to have a lot of stress put on you and not a lot of concern for your health. It WILL be your fault...never theirs as apparently they never get it wrong! You need to also understand you will be just another cog in the machine of SAP, they have taken sight off the people who make the business run.

review_title: Very glad to not work here any more
pros: Pay was excellent, benefits were good, flexibility in working remotely, good CEO. Had 6 bosses in 3 years.
cons: No real structure or discipline in how things were done. So when results were not met, there would be a reorganization, usually every 6 months. We were an acquisition so after a few years in these reorganizations they systematically moved out the people who knew about the business and brought in the SAP lifers. Then they moved everyone under them on and brought in their buddies. The new senior managers would make arbitrary decisions on who the managers under them should be. It happened at least 6 times in 3 years. The people working for the managers were way more qualified for the jobs, but not one of those positions were ever advertised. The management style was abusive, highly political, and no interest in developing employees.

review_title: Accounts receivable dept. in Prague: Unstable employment
pros: Nice new offices, international environment, good career perspectives, if you meet the right people.
cons: - Firing during the probation period - The managers don't disclose the actual reason why they are firing an employee during the probation period: they are silent almost all the time during the whole 2 months and 1/2 of employment and then - towards the end of the probation period - they come up to the employee, stating that he/she failed to reach the targets during his/her employment and they aren't sure whether they want to confirm him/her as a permanent employee, blaming it all on the employee and on his /her performance, although the employee is trying his / her best to accomplish his/her goals: a few days later , the managers fire the employee on the spot. - As a matter of fact, there are some other reasons behind a firing during the probation period: in my case, for instance, the manager noticed (after more or less 1 month of employment) that one of the team members (who had been in the company for more than 10 years) and who was supposed to take care of my whole training really disliked me and was very often mad at me, although I was trying as hard as I could to abide by their rules and to follow the trainings. - The reason why this person disliked me so much was actually related - in my opinion - to my unusual skills to speak several languages (indeed I ended up - quite by chance - in a project where all of the languages which I've been studying in the past 10 years were spoken, so this colleague was clearly envying me and was behaving exactly this way (complaining about me with the manager, stating that I wasn't paying enough attention to the trainings etc) - To assume that someone is unfit for an entry level position (I had colleagues, whose job experience at SAP was their very first one, indeed they were part-time employees, studying at the university) sounds quite suspicious, considering that I had worked for 2 years previously in similar customer service positions in other companies and I never really had issues with the work itself: it's the kind of job which can be done basically by anyone, who has basic IT skills and basic language skills. - The job itself consisted in calling the customers in order to remind them to pay for their invoices: a few days before firing me, the manager was trying to convince me that I had some mental disorder or cognitive deficit, keeping me from performing the job, which was actually an extremely easy job. - The manager said also - though - that he believed in my potential and would have helped me find another position in the same company: I applied for about 25- 30 internal positions after getting fired, but none of my applications was successful though, so I spent 3 months unemployed and short of money, before receiving another job offer from another company. - Obviously the manager told the other team members to behave exactly like the colleague who was bullying me all the time: they all wanted to make me believe that I - as a matter of fact - was unfit for the job and really deserved to get fired. - During my first month of employment - indeed - only this colleague seemed to have something against me but, after some time, all of the employees (who were the manager's accomplices ) who at the very beginning used to have a friendly or neutral behavior towards me started being very strict on me , being very picky about every single (real or assumed) mistake from my side. - After spending a few years in some multinational corporations, I actually realized that - every time the managers notice there's a conflict between two employees in the same project, they usually don't bother explaining the most arrogant and senior colleague that maybe he/she's wrong to have a certain behavior towards a new joiner (they find it awkward, how can you contradict some senior colleague, who has been in the company for such a long time?), they'd rather make these 2 colleagues work in 2 different projects or - the way it happened to me, to fire one of the two employees (usually the new joiner), so that they won't have any chance to meet and work together again. - Most of the times - though - it's not that easy for an employee to find another suitable position in the same company , because the entry level positions aren't open all the time and most of the times only the senior positions are open and some employees might not fulfill the requirements for such positions. - To sum it all up: the manager(s) wanted to hire me and they chose me among other candidates: however, after realizing - 20/30 days after my starting date, that one of the senior colleagues really hated me, the manager asked the other team members (who really had nothing against me) to be as critical and strict on me as this senior colleague was, to make this person's behavior look like "normal" and shared by the other ones, in order for the manager to be able eventually to fire me for a pretextual reason.

review_title: SAP Ariba a good company but miss managed by UK Managment
cons:
ltant in London, England, England
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
I work for Ariba Consulting Team in UK and their are lot of pro: - You meet lot of smart people in the company and some of them are quite driven - Consulting team support each other except for people who are close to UK management, they only scratch the back of UK management team and don't carry about rest. - The product is being upgraded, although bit slowly according to me but going in right direction. - Regional (EMEA) Management is quite good and willing to listen, they are very helpful and provide full support. The EMEA management want to get things right and are willing to make investment /commitment to make things happen. - Opportunity to work with number of different clients with unique business requirements.
Cons
I guess the con is that UK Management Team - will not support you if you are not in their good books irrespective of valid business rational. - you need to be a female to grow within the EMEA team - you may be given opportunities, if you become 'yes man' or women. Basically, you will not have to apply your mind in front of UK Management and accept their wrong decision making as your fault. - allowed to be micro managed and sometime to the extent that one has to do the things in the same manner or sequence as they do although their is no other reason. - you will have to go through a tick box exercise and actual work, concerns, issues or challenges are not even discussed. - UK team have made Ariba UK consulting team as personal fiefdom. I don't think they fully embrace the SAP practices in fully and implement things around edges.

review_title: NSC - Good experience but with room for improvement
cons:
ltant in Lisbon
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
- Projects: possibility to work on great multinational and multicultural projects with the whole SAP structure behind you to ensure you succeed - Benefits: Good benefits package, especially if you're a senior - Other perks: you can see the doctor at the office and there's free fruit and coffee every day
Cons
- Facilities: lack of office space and parking spots, as the company is growing - Talent retention: there is no retention policy in Human Resources, which causes consultants with valuable skills to be hired by the competition - Work life balance: While management is generally OK with it, there is no policy on working remotely and the burden is on the consultant to always ask and explain him/herself about it - Teams are too large for a manager to manage effectively, making communication and companionship within the team very difficult - Managers: Managers don't work with you on the projects, they are simply managing each team's project staffing. This opens the door to subjective performance reviews, as the managers don't see themselves the work that you produced, relying instead on third party accounts of your performance.

review_title: The cheapest company in the bay
pros: - You can chill a lot and coast along. Variable comp parts are very minimal and firings are pretty uncommon, despite bad performance. TLDR: Perfect company for coasting and retirement. - Perks are OK (but not great)
cons: Working for SAP, especially if you are the Bay Area and you want to have a career with a meaningful purpose or comp is one of the worst life choices you can make. There's a ton of problems at SAP, but I believe many of them are symptoms of an extremely below market compensation and incentive structure which nurtures and rewards a culture of mediocrity. They key problem areas are: Compensation (Note this is from the perspective of Engineering): - The compensation at SAP Palo Alto is severely below market. New Grads often get only around ~100k TC (total incl, bonus and stock!) and even as a seasoned engineer and high performer it is extremely difficult to get 200k total comp. Most folks I know earn between 100-150k (again incl. bonus and stocks) and have around 5YoE and are usually pretty high performing. While "100-150k" sounds like a lot somewhere else this is ridiculously bad for a company of SAP's size in the bay area when you are a high performer. Almost every startup, no matter how small will pay you more Base than what SAP offers as Total Comp and give you a generous stock option package on top. Most bigger companies of SAP's size will pay you at least 1.5x, often times 2x than SAP (FANG would go even 2.5x-3x if you get lucky) . Furthermore the salary progression is very slow. If you progress as a high performer you get often times only between 2-4% salary increase per year. During a promotion you will normally get at max only get 10/11% more, often times less than that. Note typically you can get a promotion earliest every 2 years. On top of that almost everyone with your YoE gets paid the same, no matter how good or bad you're performing. I.e. If you perform 10x to the worst person in your team, you're probably still just earning about the same, max 10% more. Managers get a very small bonus and salary raise pool that they have to distribute between folks. Furthermore the pool size doesn't depend on the performance of the team. If you are in a team with only high performers the pool size is the like in teams with only low performers. Altogether the comp level is extremely low and the system does not reward performance, therefore everybody is just coasting and the whole atmosphere is very demoralizing. Extremely political and bad decision making: Most of the middle management is extremely political and just trying to keep their job / justify their existence and increase their teams headcount instead of actually making the right technology and product decisions in the interest of the company. I had one SVP even admitting this to me and saying that at "SAP SVPs are like dukes fighting to keep power over their own little kingdom". If you want to experience GoT real life, be SAP's guest. Often multiple organizations worldwide work on a very similar problem but instead of joining forces they're just making up arbitrary differences to avoid a conflict and keep their SVPs independent. Important technology decisions are made by SVPs and Architects in committees where 90% of the people haven't written a single line of code in decades. Every tech decision is affected by the "not-invented-here-syndrome" and instead of reusing existing proven OSS tech for non-differentiated components a bad SAP-copy of a technology is developed, because leaders believe they can easier sell proprietary SAP tech for top $$$ to their customers. This works in the beginning with some naive SAP fanboy customers but never leads to an industry leading product or technology and long term always leads to the same result: SAP's losing in favor of a much better and cheaper competitor. In general whoever makes the best PPT slides and talks the loudest gets to make decision and the promotion. SAP is a sales machine and not a tech company, unfortunately. Immigration Policies: The immigration policies at SAP are an absolute nightmare. First of all you have to beg your manager and HR to file H1Bs and GC. For GC you have to be 3 years with the company until they start the process, unless you get an exception approval. If you leave the company within 1 year after getting the GC, you have to pay back all the lawyer and filing expenses. The immigration team (HR and Lawyers) are extremely unresponsive and often times don't answer for weeks or months to your emails. You basically have to beg your manager to follow up with HR / immigration on your behalf and even your manager doesn't get answers for weeks at times. Furthermore they have some weird policies like that you have to be in particular T level (career level at sap) to file a GC in a particular category. For example for GC EB-3 you have to be in T2. If you are already in T3 this means in some cases your manager has to temporarily demote you to T2 in order to start the GC process which is just another way of keeping your comp down. Many folks I know are visa-trapped inside SAP on an L1 or E1 visa and SAP uses the visa trap to keep folks inside the company on their subpar comp. Those folks would leave the company within a blink of an eye once they get the right visa. Subpar technology and Engineering: The engineering and technology at SAP is pretty bad overall. Because of the politics often times bad tech decisions are made and because of the bad comp SAP can't get the right talent to consistently create good tech. A lot of the core technologies that you have to use in your day-to-day work were developed and are pushed by the HQ in Walldorf where people live in their own bubble and rarely hear or acknowledge of tech industry trends before it's too late. Over-engineering is a serious problem as well. For context I just want to add that I've worked at SAP multiple years, both in Walldorf HQ and in Palo Alto. The experiences described not only represent my personal ones but are consistent with the experiences of my network in multiple teams and locations, incl. US, Germany and India. The only location which I would mildly recommend is SAP Germany due to very good perks and OK-ish comp (that being said there are much better alternatives there too). It honestly appears like a miracle to me that SAP has a 4.4 Glassdoor rating and is rated as a Best Place to work, but can probably be explained with SAP being very good at Marketing bad stuff as Gold.

review_title: One of the best choices for Bulgaria
pros: Excellent working environment. Company cares about almost everything which can make employess feel comfortable e.g. ergonomic workplaces, different types of meeting rooms, different choice of food and beverages. Feedback is constantly requested and improvements are actually made. There are a lot of different teams and a variety of projects and technologies to choose from. The company invests in its people in different aspects - support for carreer development, education even help for solving personal issues. In comparison with other workplaces in Bulgaria SAP is really an excellent choice.
cons: There is no effective control for the lowest management level. Sometimes hired team leads do not understand neither software development nor people management but just have hunger for a management career. The company has very low internal control for identifying such toxic bosses supported by microteam of submerges. So as many other large companies you can get in the situation to love your company and job and things you do, but be forced to go away from your toxic boss.

review_title: Good for retirement. Bad for people starting their careers
pros: Good Benefits Beautiful Campus (Palo Alto) Free Lunch Good WL Balance Job Security (despite the horrible lay offs)
cons: Old Giant Slow work Says its innovative and cutting edge, but not really Flashy promises and products that lack Management lacks vision Overall, I believe it was my mistake to join the company as a fresh graduate. SAP is the company you join when you want to retire and end your career. You will not find much growth. You will not learn many new things. People stick with the company just to get their benefits, do their 9-5 and go back home to family. If that is what you want, SAP is awesome. If you are a graduate and want to advance your career, STAY AWAY My general feeling about SAP is that the company is afloat because many other enterprises use their products and its expensive to switch. No new innovation is done here.

pros: The people are some of the best - bright, happy to help, take full ownership and produce impressive work. This includes the devs, architects and Product. Management cares and is good. I'm fortunate to be working on a modern, exciting, visible project, though obviously SAP also has projects that are less so. Competitive salaries, great benefits. Standing desk for those who need. Work-life balance and vacation days are as they should be. Fair and clearly defined opportunities for career advancement, both as an IC and along the management track, I believe in their vision, which emphasizes cloud done right and avoiding proprietary in favor of open and interoperable.
cons: Compared to other companies I've worked at in Israel, certain benefits are slightly lacking. We don't do "fun days" as often, the cafeterias are minimally stocked, and the Cibus rules are restrictive (though I understand the rationale - they invest heavily in the amazing, subsidized on-site cafeterias).
